Description.val:
The Information Systems Security Program (ISSP) ensures the protection of Navy and joint cyberspace systems from exploitation and attack.  Cyberspace systems include wired and wireless telecommunications systems, information technology (IT) systems, and the content processed, stored, or transmitted therein. ISSP includes protection of the Navy's National Security Systems (NSS).

ISSP provides for the procurement of Communications Security (COMSEC) equipment to Navy ships, shore sites, aircraft, Marine Corps, and United States Coast Guard (USCG) via the Navy Crypto Modernization (CM) and Key Management (KM) programs.  ISSP protects information systems from unauthorized access or modification of information, and against the denial of service to authorized users or provision of service to unauthorized users.  Information Assurance (IA) / Computer Network Defense (CND) is a layered protection strategy, using Commercial Off-The-Shelf (COTS) and Government Off-The-Shelf (GOTS) hardware and software products that collectively provide an effective Network Security Infrastructure (multiple level security mechanisms and ability to detect and react to intrusions).  IA/CND is critical in protecting our ability to wage Network Centric Warfare (NCW) and improving network defense and security wholeness.

The rapid change in the underlying commercial and government cyber infrastructures makes cyber security an increasingly complex and dynamic problem. ISSP provides the Navy's warfighter the essential information trust characteristics of availability, confidentiality, integrity, authentication, and non-repudiation.   IA/CND, key supporting cyber security activities, must evolve quickly to meet the rapidly evolving threats and vulnerabilities.  Implementing ISSP requires new acquisition approaches to stay ahead of the adversary, including nation-states, terrorist, and criminal organizations.

The program provides hardware and software to the Navy with these cyber security capabilities: (1) defense of National Security Systems and Information; (2) assured separation of information levels and user communities, including allied, coalition, non-Governmental, Defense Industrial Base, and other public partners; (3) technologies supporting the Navy's Computer Network Defense Service Providers (CNDSP) operations; (4) assured use of the Navy's telecommunications infrastructure and the wireless spectrum; (5) assurance of joint-user cyberspace domains, using a defense-in-depth architecture; (6) assurance of the critical computing base and information store; and, (7) supporting assurance technologies, including a Public Key Infrastructure (PKI). ISSP must be rapid, predictive, adaptive, and tightly coupled to cyberspace technology.

Justification.val:
The FY 2015 budget will procure the following:

Computer Network Defense (CND)(DA070): Equipment to secure Navy network information systems. Procurements within the CND Increment 2 equipment line include hardware and software such as servers, laptops, accessories and appliances that provide the following capabilities: Firewall components which provide protection for networks from unauthorized users; Virtual Private Networks (VPN) which provide encrypted "Point-to-Point" virtual communication networks; System and Host-Based Protection tools such as Host Based Security System (HBSS); Remediation tools, Boundary Protection, Email/Web Content Filtering, Intrusion Prevention Systems (IPS); network management tools; and supporting infrastructure such as Inner Security Screening Router (ISSR) / Outer Security Screening Router (OSSR), load balancers, and Keyboard, Video, and Mouse (KVM) switches. Hardware and software will also be procured to support the Outside the Continental United States (OCONUS) Navy Enterprise Network (ONE-Net) security initiative. Funds also support the Pre-Planned Product Improvement (P3I) initiative for Navy Cyber Defense Operations Command (NCDOC) and the Cyber Remediation initiative to improve network defense and security wholeness.

Cyber Virtual Secure Enclave (VSE)(DA070): Equipment to provide Client Nodes (CN) and deployable Fly Away Kits (FAK), in order to support expanded user level access to the existing system architecture which is required for the execution of various operational plans.  

Navy Cryptography (Crypto)(DA071): Crypto equipment, which includes families of Communications Security (COMSEC), crypto data and crypto voice products; KW-46, VINSON/Advanced Narrowband Digital Voice Terminal Cryptographic Modernization (VACM), KIV-7M (COMSEC crypto serial replacement), and the Cryptographic Universal Enclosures (CUE).

Key Management (KM) (DA005): Equipment to include Key Management Infrastructure (KMI), Management Clients (MGC), Advanced Key Processors (AKP),High Assurance Internet Protocol Equipment (HAIPE) devices, Delivery Only Clients (DOC), Simple Key Loaders (SKL), and associated ancillary equipment.  

Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) (DA018): Equipment to implement a secure infrastructure for the generation, management, delivery of digital certificates for secure electronic transactions, which include Alternate Logon Tokens (ALT), Real-Time Automated Personal Identification System (RAPIDS) hardware and software, RAPIDS v7.8.X (WIN7) hardware and software upgrades, Navy Certificate Validation Infrastructure (NCVI) SIPRNet & NIPRNet Afloat hardware and software, Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) responders, and other certificate validation mechanisms.

Name.@footnote: FY14 PKI Afloat Procurement reflects new Navy requirement in support of NCVI Afloat.  PKI Afloat procurements completed in FY14 (quantity of 25) as a lifetime buy from NCS Technologies due to end of contract date June 2014.
Alternate Logon Tokens (ALT) are procure only.  No associated installation costs.
PKI Ashore production support includes Alternate Logon Tokens (ALT) from FY14-19 and Navy Certificate Validation Infrastructure (NCVI) in FY16.
CND is designated Training Support Agent (TSA) IAW OPNAV 11102.2, CND is required to transition initial training (train the trainer) to an approved solution at the schoolhouses.

CND Inc 2 Afloat procurement/installation quantities represents one system per ship platform. The Operating System Environment (OSE) Software (SW) only variant loads software onto hardware, while the remaining variants refer to an identical software build loaded on differing hardware requirements (HW/SW, Information Assurance Tracking System (IATS) or Laptop). Depending on the build required to bring that ship to baseline, the unit cost goes from ~$29K for SW only to ~$121K for IATS. The mix of variants being fielded diff each year. Due to CND's rapid Information Technology (IT) fielding approach, CND afloat procurements vary year to year in order to deliver capabilities as determined by the CND Capabilities Steering Group (CCSG). First quarter installations reflected in the Installation Schedule are funded in the prior year in order to be able to fund the installation contracts 90 days prior to the beginning of shipboard installation work.  90 days are needed to allow sufficient time for the contractor to plan the work schedule, order material, and perform necessary fabrication.  This procedure allows installations to be scheduled in the first quarter thereby supporting Fleet availability.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Installed : Installation Name: Computer Network Defense (CND) Increment 2- Afloat

Description.val: Computer Network Defense (CND) Afloat systems (AN/UYQ-96(V)) include: System and host-based protection tools such as Host Based Security System (HBSS), remediation tools including Assured Configuration Assessment Solution (ACAS), supporting hardware and software for Department of Defense (DoD) mandated tools, Information Assurance Tracking System (IATS), Operating  System  Environment (OSE), enhanced data correlation tools, switches, ancillary devices and other related security tools.

Name.@footnote: CND is designated Training Support Agent (TSA) IAW OPNAV 11102.2, CND is required to transition equipment to an approved solution at the schoolhouses. FY16 and FY19 reflect equipment upgrades of the latest CND training baselines.  No associated install costs.
Procurement of production representative systems for the CND Production Labs.  No associated install costs.

CND Inc 2 Shore procurement/installation qty represents multiple CND architectures with an assortment of builds that are specifically designed to each site.  Unit cost fluctuations vary with site type as well as variant being fielded to that site. Installation cost will vary based on equipment installed/removed as well as location.  In accordance with CND's rapid IT fielding, CND procurement costs will vary year to year due to delivering capabilities determined by the CND Capabilities Steering Group (CCSG).  FY16 unit cost increase for NOC sites supports cyber remediation effort to provide Cyber Remediation initiatives within the Navy CND program in order to achieve improved network defense and security wholeness.

FY16 unit cost increase for NCDOC sites supports cyber remediation effort to provide Cyber Remediation initiatives within the Navy CND program in order to achieve improved network defense and security wholeness.
Name.val: 1.1.4) Navy Cyber Defense Operations Command (NCDOC) - NonOrganic

Name.@footnote: FY16 unit cost increase for TNOSC sites supports cyber remediation effort to provide Cyber Remediation initiatives within the Navy CND program in order to achieve improved network defense and security wholeness.
Name.val: 1.1.5) Theater Network Operations & Security Center (TNOSC) - NonOrganic

Name.@footnote: ONE-Net Security initiative is the reconfiguration effort to create increased failover capability between ONE-Net sites. POR is accelerating efforts to collapse Local Network Security Center (LNSC) sites by FY16 due to minimize sites with EOS equipment.

Pre-Planned Product Improvement (P3I) initiative for Navy Cyber Defense Operations Command (NCDOC) supports a major upgrade of end-of-life equipment with more robust capability that is required to support the NCDOC mission.  Initial buy anticipated in FY15 with continuing improvements planned in the out years.  Installation costs reduced from FY15 to FY16 due to fewer capabilities being delivered.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Installed : Installation Name: Computer Network Defense (CND) Increment 2- Shore

Description.val: CND Ashore systems (AN/FYC-23) are located at IT-21 Networks Operation Centers (NOCs), Outside the Continental United States (OCONUS) Navy Enterprise Network (ONE-Net) Information Assurance Suite (IAS), Broadcast Control Authorities (BCA), and Navy Cyber Defense Operations Command (NCDOC), and CND production labs.  The ONE-Net security initiative consolidates Local Network Service Centers (LNSC) to their parent Theater Network Operations & Security Center (TNOSCs) for more efficient operation and enables greater failover capability between ONE-Net sites.  The Virtual Training Environment initiative supports equipment upgrades at the Navy schoolhouses.  The Pre-Planned Product Improvement (P3I) initiative for NCDOC which upgrades end-of-life equipment with more robust capability required at NCDOC.  NCDOC is the designated Navy CND service provider, whose mission is to coordinate, monitor, analyze, and oversee the defense of Navy computer networks, NOCs, systems and is responsible for accomplishing CND missions as assigned by Commander, U.S. Tenth Fleet (COMTENTHFLT) and Commander, U.S. Cyber Command (USCC).  NOCs provide regional protection to shore and afloat assets within their area of responsibility (AOR), however, NCDOC provides Navy-wide monitoring and defense for all the Navy NOCs.  This effort will transition Information Assurance (IA) systems and capabilities from NCDOC.  Resources will be used to upgrade sensor grids and data correlation tools, and to enhance the Cyber Defense Mission Support System (CDMSS) architectural framework to provide the necessary storage capability and processing power for NCDOC to successfully ingest and analyze increased volumes of data from additional sources; information will then be disseminated to Navy decision makers as their roles require. Deployment of Cyber Remediation will achieve improved network defense and security wholeness, countering intruders and attacks aimed at disrupting tactical communications at the afloat gateways and shore commands. Cyber Remediation capabilities will accelerate the Navy's ability to prevent, constrain and mitigate cyber-attacks and critical vulnerabilities as well as provide greater resiliency, awareness, data analytics, redundancy and diversity into the Navy's Defense-in-Depth (DiD) strategy.

Name.@footnote: Fly Away Kits (FAK) installations are funded by the cognizant programs and services

ImplementationMethodName.val: Installed : Installation Name: Cyber VSE Afloat - Application Service Points

Description.val: Cyber Security Virtual Secure Enclave (VSE) is the follow-on limited transition of capabilities from the Office of the Secretary of Defense (OSD) / Pacific Command (PACOM) sponsored VSE Joint Capability Technology Demonstration (JCTD). The technology provides a virtual secure enclave within existing networks that create a two-way encrypted tunnel between locations. The procurement funds are to procure hardware nodes and accompanying software for Application Service Points (ASP) and deployable Fly Away Kits (FAK), in order to provide an assured Command & Control (C2) capability for JTF-519 in the PACOM Area of Responsibility (AOR).  This capability will be supported and maintained under Computer Network Defense (CND) specifically to support Joint Task Force (JTF)-519/PACOM urgent operational need until such time as an enterprise solution is fielded.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Installed : Installation Name: Cyber VSE Ashore (B Kits)

Description.val: Cyber Security Virtual Secure Enclave (VSE) is the follow-on limited transition of capabilities from the Office of the Secretary of Defense (OSD)/ Pacific Command (PACOM) sponsored VSE Joint Capability Technology Demonstration (JCTD). The technology provides a virtual secure enclave within existing networks that create a two-way encrypted tunnel between locations. The procurement funds are to procure hardware nodes and accompanying software for shore Application Service Points (ASP), System Administration Nodes (SAN) and Client Nodes (CN) in order to provide an assured Command & Control (C2) capability for JTF-519 in the PACOM Area of Responsibility. This capability will be supported and maintained under Computer Network Defense (CND) specifically to support the Joint Task Force (JTF) - 519/PACOM urgent operational need until such time as an enterprise solution is fielded.

COMSEC Serial Crypto Replacement (Organic) are procurements of KIV-7M units (procure only).
KW-46 increase in unit cost supports change in requirement to support surface Fleet Broadcast.

VACM Milestone C (MS C) shifted from 4QFY13 to 2QFY14, due to change in Air Force schedule.   Low Rate Initial Production (LRIP) procurements shifted from FY13 to FY14 accordingly.   VACM unit cost decreases in FY18 due to the difference in crypto configuration for United States Coast Guard (USCG) and Marine compared to Navy configuration.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Installed : Installation Name: Communications Security (COMSEC / CRYPTO) - Afloat

Description.val:
Procurements within the Crypto equipment line include various families of Communications Security (COMSEC), Transmission Security (TRANSEC), crypto data and crypto voice products.  

Crypto Data products  include KIV-7M (device used for COMSEC crypto serial replacement which is the replacement for the WALBURN  family, the SAVILLE family, KW-46, and KL-51 crypto devices), Enhanced Firefly (EFF), Cryptographic Universal Enclosures (CUE),  Identification Friend or Foe (IFF) devices, In-Line Network Encryptors (INE) (to include KG-175A, KG-175D, KG-175G, KOV-26, KIV-54, KG-175X, KG-250, KG-250X), KG-45A,  AN-PYQ-20(v)(c) formerly KL-51M (laptop, suitcase and components), KGV-135A, KOK-23, KG 40AR, and KO2 enclosure replacement (HNF 2/3). Associated ancillary equipment, rack mount enclosures and parts are also included. 

Crypto Voice products include Tactical Secure Gateway (TSG), voice system cryptographic equipment,  VINSON/Advanced Narrowband Digital Voice Terminal Cryptographic Modernization (VACM), AN/USC 43 (v)M, KY-57, KY-58, KY-99, KY-100, Next Generation Internet Protocol Phones (Next Generation IP Phones/Call Manager), and Navy certificate validation infrastructure cards-13.

Name.@footnote: Installations are funded by the cognizant programs and services for procure only hardware.

VACM procurement only (organic) quantities represent devices. FY14 procurements represent Low Rate Initial Production (LRIP) procurement. FY15 procurements represent Full Rate Production (FRP) procurements. LRIP unit costs are higher than FRP unit costs due to estimated contract cost.

Procurements within the Crypto equipment line include various families of Communications Security (COMSEC), Transmission Security (TRANSEC), crypto data and crypto voice products.

Crypto Data products include KIV-7M (device used for COMSEC Crypto Serial Replacement which is the replacement for the WALBURN family, the SAVILLE family, KW-46, and KL-51 crypto devices), Enhanced Firefly (EFF), Cryptographic Universal Enclosures (CUE), Indentification Friend or Foe (IFF) devices, In-Line Network Encryptors (INE) (to include KG-175A, KG-175D, KG-175G, KOV-26, KIV-54, KG-175X, KG-250, KG-250X), KG-45A, AN-PYQ-20(v)(c) formerly KL-51M (laptop, suitcase and components), KGV-135A, KOK-23, KG 40AR, and KO2 enclosure replacement (HNF 2/3). Associated ancillary equipment, rack mount enclosures and parts are also included.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Not Installed - Next Generation Fill Device
Installed : Installation Name: Key Management Infrastructure (KMI) - Afloat

Description.val:
Description: Key Management is a collection of Tier 2 equipment (Local Management Device (LMD)/Key Processor (KP)) and Tier 3 equipment (Simple Key Loader (SKL), Tactical Key Loader (TKL), Next Generation fill devices and Communications Security (COMSEC) Manager Work Station (CMWS)). The next generation Key Management Tier 2 product to replace the legacy LMD/KP Electronic Key Management System (EKMS) is Key Management Infrastructure (KMI). KMI includes the Management Client (MGC), Advanced Key Processor (AKP), High Assurance Internet Protocol Equipment (HAIPE) devices, and Delivery Only Client (DOC).

KMI is the next generation key management system that provides for net-centric, web based architecture for the ordering, management and distribution of all cryptographic key material to support DoN users.  KMI is a National Security Agency (NSA) program with the services procuring and deploying the Manager Client / AKP, MGC, HAIPE or DOC to replace the EKMS Local Management Device (LMD) / KP platforms. 

The Next Gen Fill device will replace SKL which stores, manages, transfers and loads cryptographic key material and COMSEC data through automatic loading of End Cryptographic Units (ECU).  Specifically, the SKL and its predecessor Data Transfer Device (DTD) provides the next generation DTD, which is based on a Personal Computer Memory Card International Association card (crypto engine) and Commercial-off-the-Shelf (COTS) notebook / palmtop computer running Government-off-the-Shelf (GOTS) software.  Data Management Devices provide intermediate key management to incorporate Mission Planning capabilities to the key packages.

Name.@footnote: Next Gen Fill devices will support Crypto Mod initiatives for KMI awareness and will replace SKLs starting in FY16.
KMI Spiral 1 and Spiral 2 procurement cost was adjusted to align with the NSA KMI full rate production contract.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Not Installed - Next Generation Fill Device

The next generation Key Management Tier 2 product to replace the legacy LMD/KP Electronic Key Management System (EKMS) is Key Management Infrastructure (KMI). KMI includes the Management Client (MGC), Advanced Key Processor (AKP), High Assurance Internet Protocol Equipment (HAIPE) devices, and Delivery Only Client (DOC).

KMI is the next generation key management system that provides for net-centric, web based architecture for the ordering, management and distribution of all cryptographic key material to support DoN users.  KMI is a National Security Agency (NSA) program with the services procuring and deploying the Manager Client / AKP, MGC, HAIPE or DOC to replace the EKMS Local Management Device (LMD) / KP platforms. 

The Next Gen Fill device will replace SKL which stores, manages, transfers and loads cryptographic key material and COMSEC data through automatic loading of End Cryptographic Units (ECU).
